2615F5546E8C4D16A710779B5B372DE3.description: MAPA.E.70: evaluate reports based on data

947D441003F24A1BB3240EDEE4918962.description: MAPA.E.69: use data from a randomized experiment to compare two treatments; use simulations to decide if differences between parameters are significant

60D2501560744EC8A244F1194D0D9688.description: MAPA.E.68: use data from a sample survey to estimate a population mean or proportion; develop a margin of error through the use of simulation models for random sampling

5550E2AF57104840953FBB52D828831B.description: MAPA.E.67: recognize the purposes of and differences among sample surveys, experiments, and observational studies; explain how randomization relates to each

6FE55A90F6A14341822B018D9240C1ED.description: MAPA.E.66: decide if a specified model is consistent with results from a given data-generating process, (e.g., using simulation; for example, a model says a spinning coin falls heads up with probability 0.5; would a result of 5 tails in a row cause you to question the model?)

82D5099F7599466B8EF3676790E91F80.description: MAPA.E.65: understand statistics as a process for making inferences about population parameters based on a random sample from that population

61E29DDAE3104C428C36B834DA760B21.description: MAPA.E.64: use the mean and standard deviation of a data set to fit it to a normal distribution and to estimate population percentages; recognize that there are data sets for which such a procedure is not appropriate; use calculators, spreadsheets, and tables to estimate areas under the normal curve

C7E1158DC922493CAC21D5EA72F77D7D.description: MAPA.E.63: use statistics appropriate to the shape of the data distribution to compare center (median, mean) and spread(interquartile, range, standard deviation) of two or more different data sets

3BBB6141F3964844B26642D73DEAAB54.description: MAPA.E.62: analyze decisions and strategies using probability concepts (e.g., product testing, medical testing, pulling a hockey goalie at the end of a game)

D686A9EAA5934D5E8270C99140A7C1AB.description: MAPA.E.61: use probabilities to make fair decisions (e.g., drawing by lots, using a random number generator)

AA400B565FFE409F8808FF90318D6322.description: MAPA.E.60: evaluate and compare strategies on the basis of expected values (e.g., compare a high-deductible versus a low-deductible automobile insurance policy using various, but reasonable, chances of having a minor or a major accident)

0619925126AD4CCBA86F2CDD8CC7F082.description: MAPA.E.59: find the expected payoff for a game of chance (e.g., find the expected winnings from a state lottery ticket or a game at a fast-food restaurant)

DDF60A64C1554DBABC970053C64A1DC9.description: MAPA.E.58: weigh the possible outcomes of a decision by assigning probabilities to payoff values and finding expected values

4CF2134F2A1E472C91FAAF8F10BB4E25.description: MAPA.E.57: develop a probability distribution for a random variable defined for a sample space in which probabilities are assigned empirically; find the expected value (e.g., find a current data distribution on the number of TV sets per household in the United States, and calculate the expected number of sets per household; how many TV sets would you expect to find in 100 randomly selected households?)

0754D7A6514A4547861FA124CC63BF6B.description: MAPA.E.56: develop a probability distribution for a random variable defined for a sample space in which theoretical probabilities can be calculated; find the expected value (e.g., find the theoretical probability distribution for the number of correct answers obtained by guessing on all five questions of a multiple-choice test where each question has four choices, and find the expected grade under various grading schemes)

C23C358E4575489C8AFF4EC719E8764F.description: MAPA.E.55: calculate the expected value of a random variable; interpret it as the mean of the probability distribution

B3FDE0212AD74AAEA2CA6986A4E53E99.description: MAPA.E.54: define a random variable for a quantity of interest by assigning a numerical value to each event in a sample space; graph the corresponding probability distribution using the same graphical displays as for data distributions

25367377A73D486E8F8F74A932B9F5A1.description: MAPA.E.53: use permutations and combinations to compute probabilities of compound events and solve problems

3E871723F0CB407CA0199B1CA4A2BFD4.description: MAPA.E.52: apply the general Multiplication Rule in a uniform probability model, P(A and B) = [P(A)]x[P(B\A)] =[P(B)]x[P(A\B)], and interpret the answer in terms of the model

7CA05BBBBDED4921BA28CB08DE5B7A6C.description: MAPA.D.51: multiply a vector (regarded as a matrix with one column) by a matrix of suitable dimensions to produce another vector; work with matrices as transformations of vectors

15544D0B8D83448BA098D331273AD219.description: MAPA.D.50: compute the magnitude of a scalar multiple cv using \\cv\\ = \c\v; compute the direction of cv knowing that when \c\v not equal to 0, the direction of cv is either along v (for c > 0) or against v (for c < 0)

FE9380BB1C4849DD920ABAE38B45E75A.description: MAPA.D.49: represent scalar multiplication graphically by scaling vectors and possibly reversing their direction; perform scalar multiplication component-wise, (e.g., as c(vx, vy) = (cvx, cvy))

6F668BF481284E0C96882C44F5F70D85.description: MAPA.D.48: multiply a vector by a scalar

9BE65C5DAEEA48D3AA3980FF3CF3BD4B.description: MAPA.D.47: understand vector subtraction v - w as v + (-w), where (-w) is the additive inverse of w, with the same magnitude as w and pointing in the opposite direction; represent vector subtraction graphically by connecting the tips in the appropriate order, and perform vector subtraction component-wise

6B52AE8397034A18A0B512AEB71588A5.description: MAPA.D.46: given two vectors in magnitude and direction form, determine the magnitude and direction of their sum

78DDD754A73442EAAD3702B426ABF7C3.description: MAPA.D.45: add vectors end-to-end, component-wise, and by the parallelogram rule; understand that the magnitude of a sum of two vectors is typically not the sum of the magnitudes

DE2FB6836109454C8BFB061D6D4DCF51.description: MAPA.D.43: solve problems involving velocity and other quantities that can be represented by vectors

2A140195E9D2497BB928AB05DDD0F78F.description: MAPA.D.42: find the components of a vector by subtracting the coordinates of an initial point from the coordinates of a terminal point

B6CF3F8E58114A0F90E0561E5D0C8A14.description: MAPA.D.41: recognize vector quantities as having both magnitude and direction; represent vector quantities by directed line segments, and use appropriate symbols for vectors and their magnitudes (e.g., v, \v\, \\v\\, v)

48D5E481BD88454AA13D17237CC50D2D.description: MAPA.D.40: calculate the distance between numbers in the complex plane as the modulus of the difference, and the midpoint of a segment as the average of the numbers at its endpoints

E2EA182F41B249BCBD1149D2F113B351.description: MAPA.D.39: represent addition, subtraction, multiplication, and conjugation of complex numbers geometrically on the complex plane; use properties of this representation for computation

E0C54E50739741249A070A307A76334C.description: MAPA.D.38: represent complex numbers on the complex plane in rectangular and polar form (including real and imaginary numbers), and explain why the rectangular and polar forms of a given complex number represent the same number

CF40EDA08DBA492C8CA2C72414A2B313.description: MAPA.D.37: find the conjugate of a complex number; use conjugates to find moduli and quotients of complex numbers

828284DD56664907998C4BEE0874F52A.description: MAPA.D.36: understand that, unlike multiplication of numbers, matrix multiplication for square matrices is not a commutative operation, but still satisfies the associative and distributive properties

125B80897D774D789823151F44B06336.description: MAPA.D.35: add, subtract, and multiply matrices of appropriate dimensions

918C1251D848499C833545C054B67FDA.description: MAPA.D.34: multiply matrices by scalars to produce new matrices, (e.g., as when all of the payoffs in a game are doubled)

D8837E513859448C8D23322966DFC1CF.description: MAPA.D.33: use matrices to represent and manipulate data, (e.g., to represent payoffs or incidence relationships in a network)

327A5B25FFC44FC396E018F8D82ACD4A.description: MAPA.D.32: work with 2x2 matrices as transformations of the plane, and interpret the absolute value of the determinant in terms of area

F79298AAB7FD44109DCCF618D1E99000.description: MAPA.D.31: understand that the zero and identity matrices play a role in matrix addition and multiplication similar to the role of 0 and 1 in the real numbers. The determinant of a square matrix is nonzero if and only if the matrix has a multiplicative inverse

A0EB315E6F1B40D292B00A720073DC28.description: MAPA.C.30: derive the equation of a parabola given a focus and directrix

096A4F0F0DA9446F91690C969C7969F6.description: MAPA.C.29: derive the equations of ellipses and hyperbolas given the foci, using the fact that the sum or difference of distances from the foci is constant

E51A81303FC34A8A87302BEB80465F16.description: MAPA.C.28: understand and apply the Law of Sines and the Law of Cosines to find unknown measurements in right and non-right triangles (e.g., surveying problems, resultant forces)

97B7AC4D6D5C4E919CAF65C016B4C519.description: MAPA.C.27: prove the Laws of Sines and Cosines and use them to solve problems

B9F7D3FCA73F4006BEB9E44F9BE41237.description: MAPA.C.26: derive the formula A = (1/2)ab sin(C) for the area of a triangle by drawing an auxiliary line from a vertex perpendicular to the opposite side

2203229070564E938BB6F8BDF6D98AA4.description: MAPA.B.25: graph trigonometric functions, showing period, midline, and amplitude

5986429A6C6B4D27BE82434D6AD294EF.description: MAPA.B.24: graph functions expressed algebraically and show key features of the graph both by hand and by using technology

ADF6C645D7314949ACD465C3B74D6DC3.description: MAPA.B.23: using tables, graphs, and verbal descriptions, interpret the key characteristics of a function which models the relationship between two quantities; sketch a graph showing key features including: intercepts; interval where the function is increasing, decreasing, positive, or negative; relative maximums and minimums; symmetries; end behavior; and periodicity

DFC954A414454654A9101056C685B89F.description: MAPA.B.22: prove the Pythagorean identity (sin A)² + (cos A)² = 1 and use it to find sin A, cos A, or tan A, given sin A, cos A, or tan A, and the quadrant of the angle

654FFC0CB31C4F49A2041FFBA9F8D250.description: MAPA.B.21: choose trigonometric functions to model periodic phenomena with specified amplitude, frequency, and midline

DC40B29C0B3C47FBA5C57BCBBDDD01A1.description: MAPA.B.20: explain how the unit circle in the coordinate plane enables the extension of trigonometric functions to all real numbers, interpreted as radian measures of angles traversed counterclockwise around the unit circle

1AF630969BAB402098DAEB21185952C8.description: MAPA.B.19: understand radian measure of an angle as the length of the arc on the unit circle subtended by the angle

D44E5C7CB82648E58A3E61D8E5680551.description: MAPA.B.18: explore the continuity of functions of two independent variables in terms of the limits of such functions as (x,y) approaches a given point in the plane

4C9F64F395774F2299ABD04797B7BD24.description: MAPA.B.17: prove the addition, subtraction, and double angle formulas for sine, cosine, and tangent and use them to solve problems

E9ABDF2626BD49859F5CED69760A4893.description: MAPA.B.16: use inverse functions to solve trigonometric equations that arise in modeling contexts; evaluate the solutions using technology, and interpret them in terms of the context

98449E81AC9C4CB0BD7B3BA9FAF78958.description: MAPA.B.15: understand that restricting a trigonometric function to a domain on which it is always increasing or always decreasing allows its inverse to be constructed

2CD4C8CF72B84EABAFBB1A4996D38AAB.description: MAPA.B.14: use the unit circle to explain symmetry (odd and even) and periodicity of trigonometric functions

9AA092E8A55A4C29A4C72A1024730FC2.description: MAPA.B.13: use special triangles to determine geometrically the values of sine, cosine, tangent, cosecant, secant, cotangent for pi/3, pi/4 and pi/6, and use the unit circle to express the values of sine, cosine, tangent, cosecant, secant, and cotangent for pi - x, pi + x, and 2pi - x in terms of their values for x, where x is any real number

5F08B3AFD191479A98552C8C9D1375AC.description: MAPA.B.12: produce an invertible function from a non-invertible function by restricting the domain

B2D02113681B4371BBD86BF6342E8187.description: MAPA.A.10: solve a simple system consisting of a linear equation and a quadratic equation in two variables algebraically and graphically

CF9A93DBB9214BA187F7E746380363E8.description: MAPA.A.9: find the inverse of a matrix if it exists and use it to solve systems of linear equations (using technology for matrices of dimension 3x3 or greater)

D0811A496F1846E5BF12BF82DE226E33.description: MAPA.A.8: represent a system of linear equations as a single matrix equation in a vector variable

51AEFA5FAA294C33B3703959E499A039.description: MAPA.A.7: establish and utilize trigonometric identities to simplify expressions and verify equivalence statements (e.g., double angle, half angle, reciprocal, quotient, pythagorean, even, and odd)

46F8CAB631674EF6A0C25666CB1042C7.description: MAPA.A.6: graph and identify characteristics of simple polar equations including lines, circles, cardioids, limaçons and roses

A1D4C5A432B74F98A4C4580B193A948E.description: MAPA.A.5: express coordinates of points in rectangular and polar form

A08041947BD1470FB447C1703B9FB768.description: MAPA.A.4: graph equations in parametric form showing direction and endpoints where appropriate

D9A90B2308134612A4DC47FB1F9B24EF.description: MAPA.A.3: convert between Cartesian and parametric form

ACAA3E9537B84E498933726B6D3D7B20.description: MAPA.A.2: describe parametric representations of plane curves

6605C8C662D740008EFD69673935690A.description: MAPA.A.1: use mathematical induction to find and prove formulae for sums of finite series
